data.title: Suggestion: When quick open is active, fill search field with selected item when pressing left arrow key
data.body:
This would help when you search for a file, that shares name with many files in different directories and you opened the wrong one at first and want to go back to the search result to find the right file.

Of course, this could alternatively be achieved by retaining the last search result in quick open.

data.title: Smoke Test: replace in search strange behavior
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.x
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Follow the smoke and search for body
2. Replace with body2
3. Select a match and press replace

Observe: the match is not removed since body still matches. I would not expect this.

data.title: Having parameters for tasks would be very useful
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

It would be very useful to have a way of prompting for additional arguments to tasks.
Something similar to the [snippet style](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/userdefinedsnippets#_creating-your-own-snippets) could be used to prompt for additional arguments.
This way tasks, or commands like the following could be done straight from vscode:

- `bin/rails g migration AddHostNameToUrl host_name:string`
  could be defined as: `bin/rails g migration ${1:MigrationName} ${2:field:type}` 
- `bin/rails db:rollback STEP=2`
  could be defined as: `bin/rails db:rollback STEP=${1}` 

These are examples for rails/rake, but the same applies to yeoman generators

- `yo angular:controller MyNewController`
  could be defined as: `yo angular:controller ${1:ControllerName}`

data.title: confusing signature in CodeLensProvider.onDidChangeCodeLenses
Expandable objects in locals cannot be modified
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16, Linux x64
- Node: 6.5.0

The locals window allows direct modification (setting the value) of variables by double-clicking the value or using the "Set Value" context menu option.

But you can't do this with objects or arrays. Because they're expandable, there are no options available for modifying them directly in locals - instead you have to manually evaluate an assignment expression to set the appropriate value.

On a related note, setting locals to object literals fails - they can only be set to primitives, strings or array literals. What's more annoying is that if you set a local to an array literal, you can't set it back! (because it becomes expandable).

Can you allow double-click and the context menu "Set Value" to expandable variables?

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Welcome screen should probably not show if VSCode is launched with a file argument
data.body:
* close all vscode instances
* in your favorite terminal, run  `code-insiders notes.txt` where `notes.txt` does not exist on disk.

> Observe: the welcome page takes the focus

> Perhaps we could interpret that running code from the command line with a file argument indicates a  strong desire from a user to edit a file and not learn about vscode? An alternative would be to open the Welcome page, but in a background tab and focus `notes.txt`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/22369116/645feb6c-e48a-11e6-91fb-cbc201abc774.png)

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Revisit "Interface overview"
data.body:
- The arrows are tiny, barely noticeable
- `view errors and warnings` points to the wrong spot. How do we maintain this, going forward?
- Where is `Find and run all commands` pointing to? There's nothing behind it to click.
- The text is hard to read because it overlays on top of existing text
- The text's content brings nothing new to the table
- I only noticed that keybindings are there after seeing my own screenshot in this issue

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/22368861/0721da88-e489-11e6-8b86-d60377aa17f9.png)

It just looks way out of style with everything else.

I suggest to open https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/codebasics instead.

data.title: The View > Output menu item doesn't show its shortcut
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.13-1-ARCH
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|fish|TeddyDD|0.0.4|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.6|
|rest-client|humao|0.12.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.52|
|MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.3|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.0|
|RustyCode|saviorisdead|0.19.1|
|vue|seanwash|0.4.2|
|vscode-lldb|vadimcn|0.3.2|

---

Despite the shortcut being part of the standard set of shortcuts (at least under Linux, it's Ctrl+K Ctrl+H)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Check the default keybindings.json (Linux):
`{ "key": "ctrl+k ctrl+h",         "command": "workbench.action.output.toggleOutput" },`
2. Look at the View menu, the "Output" item has no shortcut listed. I spent a few minutes trying to add one only to find that it already existed, it just wasn't being shown in the menu.

data.title: Missing React syntax highlight for object-value
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

**See this picture** https://1drv.ms/i/s!AopesDuNO8Zogp5mv8fihnigFgxJCQ

However, as soon as I wrap the React component inside a pair of parenthesis (...), the syntax highlighting works as expected.
```
content: (<AccountProfilePane user={this.props.currentUser} />)
```

I can confirm that it has **no syntax errors** and the language mode was set to **JavaScript React**.

data.title: Dollar sign not beeing highlighted when double clicking variable
data.body:
VS Code 1.8.1
Windows 7

When I try to double click any of the variable names with a dollar sign ($) in my angular code the dollar sign is not beeing highlighted.

For example double clicking on $scope here only marks scope.
`$scope.data = data;`

Is there an easy fix for this?

data.title: TSServer Service dies on rename
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8189808/22365098/fd563b7e-e475-11e6-8a30-e082e114260c.png)

- OS Version: Windows 100

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Trying to rename a function in a typescript class output skeleton. Renaming function _c.

```
var a;
(function(a) {
    var b= (function() {
        function b() {}
        function _c(){}

        return b;
    };
    return a.b = b;
})(a || (a={}))
```

```
[Trace - 09:35:48] TypeScript Service: canceled request with sequence number 347
[Error - 09:35:49] TSServer exited with code: 3
[Error - 09:35:49] 'navtree' request failed with error.
Error: Service died.
    at c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\typescript\out\typescriptServiceClient.js:442:46
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at TypeScriptServiceClient.serviceExited (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\typescript\out\typescriptServiceClient.js:441:37)
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\typescript\out\typescriptServiceClient.js:362:35)
    at emitTwo (events.js:111:20)
    at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191:7)
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:215:12)
[Info  - 09:35:49] Using tsserver from location: c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\typescript\node_modules\typescript\lib\tsserver.js
[Trace - 09:35:52] TypeScript Service: canceled request with sequence number 377
```

data.title: SuppressTaskName should always be true for local commands even if set to false.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.x
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

```json
        {
            "taskName": "build",
            "command": "gulp",
            "args": ["build"],
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "echoCommand": true,
            "suppressTaskName": false
        }
```
Running this results in gulp build build. For local commands this doesn't make too much sense.

data.title: Application data spread out on disk (Win10)
data.body:
Besides my installation directory, I have found that application data is stored in multiple places.

With the exception of my workspace specific stuff, I have found most (all?) of my settings in `%APPDATA%\Code - Insiders`. But then I find my extensions in `%USERPROFILE%\.vscode-insiders`.

Is this how it's supposed to be? Perhaps it's just me that find it cumbersome to locate everything.

data.title: problems HTML with the cursor when I press enter
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.4.2|

---

I show you how it works in atom.

![gif1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22363221/cd122208-e479-11e6-8895-4bfb44658f7e.gif)

then I show you how it works in VSCODE

![gif2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22363225/d96a5886-e479-11e6-801d-175290a83b60.gif)

![gif3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22363404/32bf9562-e47b-11e6-8838-3385d4943059.gif)
why when I press the "ENTER" the cursor moves to the alt attribute. Logically it should add a new line

![html json](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22500773/00846366-e877-11e6-841f-4ac111cba421.jpg)

![gif4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22500917/86f5c3c2-e877-11e6-89f0-573240eac0e3.gif)

I moved the cursor with the mouse, then I pressed enter

![gif5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22501114/5f952d76-e878-11e6-8646-2d21b95b8e11.gif)

I moved the mouse cursor to end of line, again, I have twice hit the Enter key to move to a new line. Sorry for my English. But if I moved the mouse pointer immediately to a new line the problem disappears

![gif6](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15665678/22501209/d88f948c-e878-11e6-9ebe-af4823354312.gif)

and then I press the tab key, and why is he fixated?

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I have to press "Enter" twice to move to a new line because when I click first time it returns to its original position. Although logically there should be a transition but a new line. 

Specifically I deleted all the plug-ins to show what the problem is VS CODE
